title: Smokies' Clingmans Dome closes temporarily
content: CLOSE       Swain County has yet to be paid about $39 million it is owed by the federal government. The government agreed in 2010 to pay the county $52 million for the loss of a road through the north shore area of Great Smoky Mountains National Park, but most of the debt is still outstanding. Mark Barrett          Clingmans Dome Observation Tower in Great Smoky Mountains National Park will be closed for repairs June 44-15. (Photo: Courtesy Kristina Plaas)      GREAT SMOKY MOUNTAINS NATIONAL PARK Getting to the highest point, and one of the most popular spots, in the Great Smokies will require a little patience this month.    Clingmans Dome Observation Tower, at 6,643 feet elevation, and commanding the most sweeping view – on a clear day – of the sprawling national park, will be closed June 4-15 while a rehabilitation project that began last year is completed. Workers need to apply a final surface overlay along the tower ramp, said park spokeswoman Dana Soehn.    While visitors will not be able to climb the tower, which straddles the North Carolina and Tennessee state line, the Clingmans Dome parking overlook area will remain open and offers similar scenic mountain top views.    The visitor contact station and store, the trail up to the tower, and all access to the trailheads in the vicinity, including the Mountains-to-Sea and the Appalachian Trail, will remain open.    Visitors should expect some construction traffic in the area and along the trail. They might also be pleasantly surprised, Soehn said.        Autoplay    Show Thumbnails    Show Captions    Last Slide Next Slide     "The work is weather dependent. They need five days of dry weather to accomplish the work. If visitors get up there, they may get treated, if the tower doesn't close exactly on June 4. Or, work might go faster and it might be open five days earlier," she said.    RELATED : It's blue ghost firefly time in the WNC mountains    Last year, contractors repaired deteriorated areas on the concrete columns and walls, stabilized support walls at the base of the ramp, and repaired stone masonry on the tower built in 1959.    This work has been funded through a $250,000 Partners in Preservation grant, awarded in 2016 to the Friends of the Smokies on behalf of the park after being one of the top nine, most voted for parks in the Partners in Preservation: National Parks Campaign.    The observation tower was landmark design of the National Park Service’s Mission 66 program, which started in 1956 to upgrade and transform park planning, management, architecture and the visitor experience in honor of the 50th anniversary of the National Park Service in 1966.    RELATED : Bent Creek trails closed due to rain, erosion    RELATED : Blue Ridge Parkway closed near Asheville    Clingmans Dome tower draws millions of visitors who climb the path to the tower, to see distances of up to 100 miles over the surrounding mountains and valleys. Although the path is paved, it is not ADA compliant, so it is too steep for wheelchairs or baby strollers.    The Smokies is the most visited national park in the country, last year drawing 11.3 million visitors, tying a record set the previous year.    For more information, visit www.nps.gov/grsm/planyourvisit/clingmansdome.htm .
